awd_titl_txt: OPUS:  Serpentine Perspectives on the Evolution of Predator-prey Relationships
awd_abstract_narration:
Snakes represent a major vertebrate radiation, with more than 3,400 species occupying diverse habitats on all major non-polar landmasses. Unusual feeding adaptations that allow these animals to consume over 100% of their body weight in a single meal have been critical in generating snake biodiversity. Snakes can rapidly increase the size of their digestive tracts and hearts, and have evolved injectable venoms that immobilize and digest their prey, however we lack detailed analyses of diet for even many widespread, common species. This project will gather and synthesize ~7500 diet records on 66 species in eight major lineages, and then analyze seasonal, size-related, and geographic variation in each species' diet. Statistical comparisons will then be used to infer evolutionary and ecological diet patterns among species, as well as to explore potential biomedical and conservation implications. The analysis will lead to a synthesis in a scholarly volume, Predator-prey Relationships: a Serpentine Perspective, to be submitted to a university press. The data will be made available to researchers and the general public to stimulate further research on the evolutionary ecology of snakes and predator-prey relationships. 

The organization and synthesis of these data will create valuable resources for the research community and will have the potential to expand scientific knowledge of predator-prey relationships over space and time. Both the published synthesis and the data will serve as benchmarks against which snake diets can be understood in the context of global climate change, shifts in species ranges, and planning management regimes. The book and archived data will be of interest not only to evolutionary ecologists and conservationists, but also to zookeepers, herpetoculturists, and interested lay naturalists. This project will contribute to the training of two undergraduates and will include public outreach presentations by the investigator.

por.por_cntn:
The PI spent a year?s sabbatical leave from Cornell University at the National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian Institution, SI), during which he met daily with curators and other staff in several departments concerning topics of mutual concern, presented a research seminar and a public lecture, examined approximately 1000 preserved specimens of snakes for evidence of their diets, and mentored an especially promising high school student. During the remaining period sponsored by this grant and since, he has continued to gather new data on snake feeding biology, analyze his findings, and submit them for publication.

Specific accomplishments supported in part or entirely from the NSF-OPUS grant, beginning with inception of funding and continuing to the present, include: 1) Published eight peer-reviewed journal articles and book chapters, including the most detailed ever study of a snake species? feeding habits, the first report of secondary seed dispersal by snakes (via rodent prey), and a multidisciplinary paper on spitting cobras that Science, among the most prestigious and highly cited journals, featured on its cover. 2) Four papers on conservation and two on innovations in teaching, also published in Science, PLoS Biology, and other high-profile venues. 3) Articles on vipers (eLibrary of Science) and evolution of spitting cobras (The Conversation), aimed at public education and outreach. 4) The mentored high school student, whom the PI continues to informally advise, is now in graduate school and has published about a dozen scientific papers. 5) The PI delivered more than 75 invited lectures, many of them departmental seminars at other universities, but also plenary talks at scientific congresses in the U.K., Namibia, and Ecuador, as well as presentations on snakes, conservation, and teaching to schools, state park educators, and other nature-related venues. 6) The PI has prepared for publication an 11,000-word invited perspectives piece on how relative prey weight and relative prey bulkiness (think of a pillow, awkwardly shaped but not heavy, compared to a cinder block of the same dimensions) influence ways in which diverse snakes eat a wide variety of prey. 7) Extending insights gained while studying of feeding in snakes to other organisms, like some frogs and fishes, that consume large items (work now in progress).  8) The PI is writing a book intended for a wide audience (Monkeys, Snakes, and Spears: Lucy?s Wild Legacy) which stems from his career-long studies of predator ecology and conservation, preparation for which began while sponsored by the OPUS grant.

Among the broader outcomes of the grant, the PI's research interests have increasingly emphasized anthropology, specifically interactions of dangerous snakes with humans and other primates. For example, with collaborators he has shown that these two groups repeatedly have reciprocally influenced each other?s evolution?snakes have helped shape human visual abilities and attitudes toward nature, whereas our lineage likely has influenced the evolution of spitting in cobras and other aspects of serpent biology. Placed in cultural contexts, these findings inspire a more nuanced approach to preventing snakebite accidents and coexisting with snakes. As another example, because snake venoms likely evolved primarily to facilitate killing and digesting prey, understanding what snakes eat has bearing on production of antivenoms and other treatment considerations, as well as the incorporation of venom components in blood pressure medications and other therapeutic usages.


Last Modified: 08/30/2022
Modified by: Harry W Greene
